Description: Bacterial disease from Xanthomonas spp.; small water‑soaked to brown spots on leaves, stems, and fruit, often with yellow halos, causing defoliation and scabby fruit under warm, humid conditions.
Cure: Use certified disease‑free or hot‑water/bleach‑treated seed; plant resistant varieties; rotate crops; avoid overhead watering and crowded spacing; remove debris; apply copper‑based bactericides every 7–10 days.
Maintain proper care, hygiene, and pest monitoring.

Description: Fungal disease caused by Alternaria solani. It forms concentric dark spots on older leaves and thrives in warm, moist conditions.
Cure: Use fungicides like chlorothalonil or mancozeb. Practice crop rotation and remove plant debris.

Description: Caused by Phytophthora infestans, it leads to large, irregular dark patches on leaves and stems, rapidly destroying plants in cool, wet weather.
Cure: Apply fungicides such as metalaxyl or copper-based sprays. Destroy infected plants and avoid overhead watering.
Maintain proper care, hygiene, and pest monitoring.

Description: Caused by Xanthomonas bacteria, appears as water-soaked spots on leaves and fruits. Can cause defoliation and fruit lesions.
Cure: Use copper-based bactericides, practice crop rotation and avoid overhead watering. Use disease-free seeds.

Description: Fungal disease caused by Passalora fulva, presents as yellow spots on upper leaf surfaces and olive-green mold on undersides.
Cure: Improve air circulation and apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or mancozeb.

Description: Commonly due to fungal pathogens like Septoria, creating small dark spots with a pale center on leaves.
Cure: Use copper fungicides, avoid leaf wetness, and remove infected leaves.

Description: Infestation by tiny mites causing stippling and yellowing of leaves, often with fine webbing, leading to defoliation.
Cure: Use insecticidal soap, neem oil, or miticides. Introduce predatory mites and increase humidity.

Description: Fungal disease forming dark spots with concentric rings, caused by Corynespora cassiicola, mostly affecting tomatoes.
Cure: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or azoxystrobin and remove infected leaves.

Description: Viral infection (e.g. Tomato yellow leaf curl virus) spread by whiteflies, causing curled, yellow leaves and stunted growth.
Cure: Control whiteflies with insecticides, use resistant varieties and remove infected plants.

Description: Viral disease leading to mottled patterns on leaves, reduced growth and distorted fruit, spread by contact or insects.
Cure: No cure; remove infected plants, control insect vectors, and disinfect tools.
Maintain proper care, hygiene, and pest monitoring.
